utterances: Well, that's a famous elevator hack and it's been rumored to exist for a while, even on the Internet, and this is kind of pathetic to admit, but I've written another story about that particular thing.
I once wrote a story about trying it in Manhattan.
I tried it in various places.
It works in some places and doesn't work in others.
Funny enough, none of the elevator professionals I talked to thought it was possible.
So, there maybe some kind of conspiracy that we don't know about.
All right.
Well, thank you for answering my question, but it is a possibility in some locations?
Oh, it works some places.
Absolutely.
Fantastic.
They won't tell you about it, though.
It's a dirty little secret.
Scott, thanks very much.

You do write though, about the psychology of those controls on the elevator panel, that the designers are trying to give us the illusion that we are in control of this box that hurtles us up and down.
Yeah, I guess people like control.
The ""door close"" button, for example, does not work on elevators that are 20, or so, years old.
I mean, elevators that have been introduced in the last 20 or so years, the ""door close"" building tends not to work - ""door close"" button tends not to work.
So it's like a placebo.
People just press it to make themselves feel better, and the fact is, the door eventually closes, so you think the ""door close"" button is working.
Which, you know, is like a perfect placebo.
If you pray every day for rain, one of these days you are going to be right.
Exactly.
Let's go.
Let's see if we can go out to Michael.
Michael calling us from San Francisco.
Good afternoon, gentlemen.
Thank you for the program.
Thank you.
Just have a couple of - well, one funny story.
Regarding impatience that people have on elevators.

There was a time where I came in and stuck my hands in to hold the doors open and the gentlemen was evidently late for work and became visibly agitated, hit all of the buttons on - for every floor, and then left in a huff.
I just had to laugh out loud to myself and tell him he needed to relax a little bit, so...
That's pretty funny.
Hey, gentlemen, how you doing?
That's good stuff.
The - actually, one other point and you were talking about proximity and personal space in the elevator before.
I also find it kind of fun, every once in a while, to stand a little bit closer than people are comfortable, and just watching their reactions.
Because, you are right, people do separate very much, and thank you very much for the program.
And then you should just talk to them and that'll make it even worse.
You know, people don't like talking in elevators.
Although, in my building at work, people talk a lot, so...
There are so many unwritten, but recognized rules.
Yup.
Thanks very much.
Thanks so much, Michael.
Here is an email we have from Kitty, in Grand Junction, Colorado.
We rode 90-some floors in Chicago, went to the bar, looked at the view, went back down, nothing remarkable but the view.
Months later, the same group rode 90-some floors in the Beavate(ph) building in San Francisco.
The ride was slightly bumpy and we complained that they hadn't done as good a job designing the building as they'd done in Chicago.
When the doors opened, we were greeted by the site of the wide-eyed young receptionist on the phone, saying, yeah, mom, we are all OK, but it was so scary.
You guessed it.
We'd been in the elevator during an earthquake.
Oh, that's pretty scary.
You write about some of the scary, I guess, in a way they're urban myths, about elevators.
That there's a sizable number of people who get killed every year as elevators plummet into the basement of buildings.
Yeah, elevators don't really plummet.
They don't free-fall.
I mean, of course, it's happened and you ask an elevator professional if there are instances of free-fall and they tend to just mention one.
And it is this sort of famous elevator accident at the Empire State building in 1945, I guess.
A bomber ran into the building and severed the cables and one of the elevators, with an operator on board, plummeted all the way to the bottom.
Eighty floors and she survived.
But, generally, the accidents are, you know, there are other kinds of accidents.
The elevators tend to go up, rather than down, because the counter weight, the thing at the other end of the cars, actually heavier than the elevator car itself.
And then there are all kinds of horrible things that happen when people try to get out of elevators that are sort of stuck between floors and then the elevator starts to move.
People probably have heard some of those stories.
There's the elevator's door opened and somebody steps in, and there is no elevator there.
That tends to happen with some frequency and - so I'm told.
That's a grim fate.
Here's an email from Stanley in St. Louis.
My wife was stuck was stuck in an elevator for 45 minutes.
The interesting, though probably not surprising aspect, was that the emergency phone in our elevator was pretty obviously connected to a call center in India.
That's true, I think some of the emergency - you know, the elevator companies have an emergency protocol set up, so that your call goes to a - probably to India.
So, I don't think that person is going to come save you, but maybe they have a mechanism in place to deploy someone else to come save you.
Another fascinating thing that you mentioned in your article, that elevators are, in a way, very much akin to telaportation.
Well, you go into an elevator in one place, and then you come out in another.
It is sort of like magic.
You know, it's like the door slides closed and then it opens and there's something else there.
It's like a magic trick.
It is like a magic trick.
I just hadn't thought of it that way, but maybe that's the reason, I guess, we all go blank when we are in elevators and just stare sheepishly ahead.
I don't know.
I guess people don't like to be in elevators.
So we sort of - it's something we all feel we have to endure.
We are talking about elevators, of course, with Nick Paumgarten, a staff writer for New Yorker magazine.
You are listening to Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
Susan's on the line.
Susan calling from Hickory, North Carolina.
Good afternoon.
Good afternoon.
Hickory, pretty as a postcard.
Pardon me?
Hickory, pretty as a postcard.
Yeah, it's a great place.
I moved here from California, so I really enjoy it.
The quietness, by comparison to Los Angeles.
I was working in the furniture mart in Hickory a couple of years ago and it was a real busy weekend.
I was there very early, and I got caught in the elevator and it started to shake.
And I'm claustrophobic.
So, when it started to shake and rattle, go up and then kind of fall down and shake and then it'd stop.
A friend of mine who owned the coffee shop at the bottom of the elevator was just about due, any moment, to give birth to her little girl, and she went absolutely hysterical.

So, I wasn't scared until I heard her screaming at the top of her lungs, and it's a rotunda, so up four flights of stairs, open in the middle of the building, this huge building, I could hear her screaming, oh, my God, Susan's trapped in the elevator, and she just wouldn't let it go.
And I thought, dear Lord, she's going to go into labor and I can't help her.
Because we were there so early, and, I mean, I wasn't that high up.
I was caught between like the second and third floor, but it did take them about an hour to get me out, so...
And how did they get you out?
Did they get you out through the hatch on top?
Or did they wheel it down?
Well, the little old guys that worked there - it kind of started sliding a little bit down and they got it open, kind of between floors and kind of pulled me out.
They got - they used something to pry the door open and got me out.
And I just spent the week at High Point furniture market and I really thought about that going up and down those elevators a million times.
And everybody being really close together and, you know, from every - all over the world.
And you are right.
Nobody talks.
Everybody just kind of looks and then there's all different languages spoken to at the same time and that's pretty funny.
Susan, thank you.
Good.
Hey, I just thought, you know, some people might want to hear perspective of somebody who has ridden on top of an elevator.
Ah, cool.
Just kind of curious, if your author ever had a chance to do that?
No, they wouldn't let me.
You know, I kept asking all these companies if I could do that, and I had to sign all these releases just to even go into the machine rooms.
No one would let me ride on top of the elevator.

And I thought they were nuts, but then I saw - one time I was in a shaft, looking at the elevator going by and I saw the counterweight, which is again, the thing connected to the other side, with the big weight...
Right.
